Title:
Species richness analysis and ITS rDNA phylogeny revealed the
majority of cultivable foliar endophytes from beech (Fagus sylvatica
L.)
Keywords:
Foliar forest endophytes, ITS phylogeny, induced
mutualism, dilution to extinction cultivation, species-accumulation
curves, species richness estimators, Ascomycota, Isaria farinosa,
Apiognomonia errabunda
Abstract:
Endophytic fungi are hard to detect due to their
non-pathogenic nature. We combined species and abundance data with that
obtained in an earlier study to re-evaluate current knowledge about
diversity of cultivable endophytes in Fagus sylvatica foliage. Fungal
ITS sequences were used for identification and phylogenetic analysis,
for the evaluation of morphotype concepts, and for validation of
morphological identification. Morphological and molecular delimitation
of isolates corresponded well and did not significantly change values
for species richness estimators. The present analyses largely increased
the known species richness of beech endophytes from 64 to 83 observed
and about 100 estimated taxa. According to the ITS phylogeny, beech leaf
endophytes belong to the main non-parasitic and non-lichenised orders of
Pezizomycotina and have close affinities to plant and insect
pathogens.
